title: How to write a good paragraph about myself - Quora

response.answer_text: See example: Hi! My name is Tom. I’m 16 and I live in Warsaw which is the capital of Poland. Actually I come from another city - Wroclaw, where I lived for eleven years, but five years ago, my dad decided to change his job, and we all moved to Warsaw. I have a sister – Maja. She is 18 and she had been to USA two years ago and now she studies law at the University of Warsaw. My dad works for a German company. My mom used to teatch at the University and now, she works as a computer analitist. I’m interested in computer science, music, sport and fantasy literature. Computers first appered in my life when I was seven. Then I had got my first computer. It was Commodore 64 and I remember myself thinking, that it was the best thing in the world. I was playing it whenever I could. Then I had got my first PC. At first, I was just playing computer games, but some time later, I noticed that I could do a lot more things with the computer, for example programming. Now, I can already programue in Pascal, C++ and HTML. I have my own site on the internet and I have done many programues. I hope that in the future I will get a job as a computer scientist. My favorite music band is QUEEN. I think it is the best group on the earth. Together with my sister, we are devoted Queen fans. We have all their albums, many video tapes, books, posters, gadgets and interviews. I love them, but I also like other groups like The Doors, The Baeatles, The Rolling Stones, some Polish rock groups and many others. Apart from that I’m really fascinated by Scottisch bagpipe songs, and one of my favorite albums is the „Braveheart” soundtrack. I have always been good at sports. I like playing soccer, running and swimming (also SCUBA diving and diving). I have played in many sport tournaments (football cups, handball cups, races) in which together with my team, I have won many trophys. My favorite intelectual game is chess, but I have never played it professionaly. I love fantasy literature. I read fantasy books and magazines, watch fantasy films and play role playing games in which fantasy world is used as background. Once every two weeks, I meet with my friends and we play „Middle Earth”. I’m the master of the game and they are players. We play about five hours sesion. It’s a lot of fun. „Middle Earth” is a game based on Tolkien’s books. I chose it, becouse I love everything that J.R.R. Tolkien wrote. He is my favorite writer, but I like other writers as well, for example Piers Anthony or Robert Jordan. My dream is to study computer science and to go to Japan. I love everything associated with this country. and I hope that in the future, I will learn Japanise. I want to go to Japan and stay there for a long time. I want to get a job there as a computer scientist. Now, I try to learn Japanise by myself. I already know some words and about sixty letters of their alfabeth. My parents promised me that if I learn German and English well, they will find me a Japanise teatcher. I hate spiders. When I see a spider (especialy when it’s a big one) I feel so very small and the spider seems so huge. I don’t feel scarred when I see a mouse, snake or any other animal and when I come across a spider I think: „Why is it not a mouse? Why do I always find spiders and not mise for example”. This is terrible.

If you’re one of the many who has difficulty writing about themselves, you can take the indirect approach. Ask yourself, ‘What is something I’m good at doing?’,’What are my goals and interests?’ Perhaps you enjoy writing, or you’ve always been there for your friends. Something that makes you proud, a trait, a story, or something you’re working towards. Whatever topics you think of, keep them in mind. Now, describe to yourself what makes you good at those things, what made you proud? How far along are you in reaching your goal? What makes you excel at that? Answer those questions, and all you will need to do is put that into words. Start with an introduction of the essentials, just like you’re introducing yourself to a new friend. As you continue, it’s okay to delete sentences, and backtrack sometimes. After it’s written, you can go back and edit it. If you’re writing for a specific group, you may want to add something that relates you to that group in your introduction. For example, “My name is Isiah Anderson, I enjoy writing answers on Quora, and have for a few years now. I’ve written about 150 Answers for questions, and I’m looking forward to answering 150 more!” (Shameless advertisement) Here is another example, “Hello, my name is Saiko L. Ge, this will be my fourth Psychology class! I’ve always been interested in this subject so I’m happy to be taking another class in pursuit of my dream: to become a psychologist.” Relating your introduction to the group adds a sort of connection, consider if it’s right for the piece you’re writing. Now you can fill the paragraph in by answering the questions (or other questions you’d ask yourself) and putting those answers into text. Be sure to edit it a few times, and perhaps have someone else take a look and critique what you’ve written. I’ll provide a (completely random) example below. “Hello, my name is Ellias Baker. I’ve never been a part of a reading group like this before, but I’m interested in joining and experiencing this with all of you! I’ve just moved here from Central Ontario, Canada, where I worked as a chef. Cooking has been my passion since my father gave me my first recipe book as a kid. I moved here in hopes to better pursue my passion in culinary, and so far it’s going great! I hope I can prepare something for all of you soon.”

There are times when we can write about ourselves with perfect clarity yet then become aware that we don’t want to represent ourselves flaws and all. So we upgrade the reality into the fantasy and expect ourselves to be comfortable with the tall tales we tell. So a good paragraph never reveals the revolting truths if any exist. An excellent paragraph or even a perfect paragraph could still not reveal us to whom it may concern. So we tend to write about ourselves in ways that others would hope to see us rather than as we know ourselves to be. The only real answer is to tell the truth that we are willing to tell and no more. A paragraph isn’t meant to go on and on. Probably just a dozen sentences will do. So create a list of topics such as the usual statistics would require and develop from these standard answers. Go deeper into how you have developed from being a mere child into a mere adult. Then express the way that you chose to make yourself into a better you than ever achieved before. From school years to what? College or University or straight into a job? Did you earn enough to save money towards something special like a car or a house or getting married and starting a family? Or did you start your own business and invest in yourself and those you employed or worked with? Did you become IT savvy with computers and the Internet, smartphones, audio and video equipment? Did you help others to become better in some way, too? Did you have any spiritual or faith interests that helped you to be better or achieve more? And what about your creative abilities or skills? Did you write stories, songs or poems and get published? Did you learn how to play an instrument? Were you artistic enough to paint or write music? And what of your family throughout the years? Were there struggles and then blessings or blessings and then struggles? And how would you want to be remembered or forgotten? : IF you can edit your thoughts to the point that you are delighted with your paragraph then maybe, just maybe, that will suffice… It won’t be like a CV such as I worked here, then here then here. It will be more like THANK GOD I MADE IT HERE… because every single day is a gift…

There are many ways to go about this, Chris, it mostly depends on what the paragraph is for. If the paragraph is for a class, then I usually ask myself, “Does the teacher want a literal description of me?” Ex. my height, hair color, etc. “Does the teacher want my interests?” Ex. my favorite song, color, animal, etc. “Does the teacher want my personality?” Ex. Am I sassy, calm, collected, argumentative, etc. If the paragraph is for a job, then I usually say something along the lines of, “I am a hard working, fun loving person who is generally optimistic and very energetic. I try my best to improve every day and try to take criticism as well as I can.” etc. If the paragraph is for the cover of a book, like an “About the Author,” then I usually put something about my personal life. Ex. “Madelyn Hammons has written x plays, x novels, x book series, x poems, etc.” Replace x with any number, then go on to talk about the personal details. Ex. how many pets I own, how many people I depend on, my nuclear family, etc. If the paragraph is for myself, then I write down items I want to improve. Ex. My handwriting, my smile, my optimism, etc. Or I’ll write items I want to do. Ex. bake a specific desert, go to this country, etc. Or I’ll just write my goals. Ex. help someone every day, smile to someone new, listen to music for so long, finish this assignment, etc. As I said before, there are many approaches one could take when writing about themselves and it all just depends on what the writing is for. I hope this helped.

Consider your audience. Build upward and outward from shared ground. Shed a light on what makes you similar to and different from what they could reasonably expect. Be authentic and real, but without disclosing so much that an acquaintance might be made uncomfortable by the intimacy. Here’s a general one that’s a little edgy, a little boastful, and interesting without being too revealing: I’m Elmedina Fejzulai, and my last name could score more than 100 points in a Scrabble game. From that, people guess I’m not mostly of standard-issue white-bread American heritage, although they rarely guess Nordic or Bosnian; I’ve found that to be both liberating and burdensome, although not in equal measures. I’m extroverted and bright, with a pale heart-shaped face, large dark eyes, and a superb knowledge of makeup. People who don’t know that about me think I’m younger than I am, and are sometimes surprised by the life advice I give on social media.

Thanks for the question. What is the purpose of writing the good paragraph? If it is to write it to and for yourself, I’d go inside and ask your inner self, shadow side, higher self what is admirable about you. If you are wanting to writing a good paragraph for a dating site, maybe ask yourself what you are wanting to attract and knowing you want the person to be authentic and like your authentic self - if that is the case. If it is for an interview, research the strengths and qualities needed and how your unique qualities and aspects serve and are a fit. If it is for marketing, see if you can step out of your own skin and imagine you are your best friend writing about you. This can help if you find it hard to write good things about yourself. Or, you can do what I did for my amazon author page and have someone who knows you really well do it for you. You might feel uncomfortable with what they say, especially if you were raised in a culture where you are not taught to say good things about yourself because it is ‘showing off’, yet if you allow logic some space, you’ll find it is hard to argue with what they are saying, and especially if it is a friend who is intelligent, practical and doesn’t exaggerate. I hope this helps.

Here are a few ways: The more detailed and personal it is, the less it will sound like any person, and the more it will be “good”.In terms of the way of writing, I suggest you imitate a writer whom you admire. For example, I admire Ernest Hemingway who wrote very short sentences but with very powerful verbs. My youngest daughter is really into Stephen King, reads him a lot, and can imitate his style effectively.In terms of length, the word paragraph has many meanings. If you write your paragraph in the form of a monologue, for example, it is traditional to keep it one paragraph no matter how long it is. Some plays have paragraphs that go on for several pages since only one person is talking. I tell my students to restrict themselves to a certain number of words. But if someone is asking for one paragraph, that usually means it should be fairly short (perhaps 300 words). As a result, stick to one central point or short anecdote about yourself.Have some fun. That doesn’t mean try to be funny. For me that means be creative or unusual in some way. An example would be to use a lot of metaphors (“I’m a dark pencil in a set of crayons.”) Another might be to use interjections (“like” or “wanna”) that sound like you, whether it be in your accent or your quirky way of phrasing things.

Everybody has a way that suits them and there are some good ideas on this thread. My way would be to just start writing things about myself, without much self-censoring, just random highlights that come quickly to mind. When there’s a page or so of these, see if there are some themes that unite the random thoughts, and collate them to form a readable paragraph. During the process, see if some written items trigger more of the same or remind you of something important that was missing, and add it. Keep in mind that the reason for writing the paragraph makes a difference in focus/main theme. A school assignment has a different purpose than a cover letter for a job, for example. Also, a paragraph is not enough to do a biography, so don’t try. Starting with something significant to you, build the paragraph. These days, I would also save such a thing, for review next year, to see how/if my thoughts had changed. It’s why some folks keep a diary.

My name is Mahinur Akter Monika. I am 13 years old. I live in Dhaka city. I am a student in class 7. I read in Shahajuddin Sarker Model School. My school starts at 8 am and finishes at 1 p.m. I am studying Bangla, English, Maths, Social science, General science, Religion in the school. I go to school on foot and return home by rickshaw. All the teachers at my school are very friendly and helpful. I love my school very much.I live with my parents. I have one brother and one sister. They are students too. My father is a businessman. My mother is a housewife. On holidays, she cooks special dishes. She works at home. My hobby is gardening. I work in my garden in the afternoon. I enjoy cricket very much. During leisure I read novels, storybooks a watch T.V. I always help the poor. I teach the illiterate when I go to my village home during holidays.

This is one of the things that most readers do not like ... The reason is not whether you accuse yourself or talk about the flaws you are suffering ... others will not accept praise for yourself. This is something that leaves others to do the evaluation. But there is a way to be very acceptable ... Asking readers to help solve a problem ... When the person reacts with you will ask you some questions and then you can answer the beautiful things that you see as good qualities that you have. For example, he will ask .. Are you nervous .. Your answer will be ... Yes Sometimes I am nervous but most of the time fun and clear ... This will be acceptable and will understand the other party you are a nice person .. But if you wrote or talked to someone else .. I'm nice ... I'm fun .. I'm pretty .. That would not be acceptable.

Writing about oneself is always interesting. If you want to write a good paragraph on yourself then you should take care of following things: You should be honest to yourself because we can never pretend to be someone which we are not.You have both positives and negatives in your personality so mention both.Introducing yourself is most important so take care that it should be very effective.In the paragraph you can describe about your attitude, behavior, likes, dislikes, your preferences, your aim in life etc the list is endless.You can conclude with an optimistic view about yourself.

Try these three simple steps: Write an unfiltered, brief account of your greatest passions, convictions, your heritage or anything else you believe defines you. Write as if nobody will ever see it. Speak from your heart and allow vulnerability and even obnoxiousness to ride shotgun. (Authenticity often requires acknowledging vulnerabilities, albeit without embellishing or flaunting them. And passion has the power not only to inspire but to annoy, which is okay.)Now edit for self-incriminating or overly-personal material, excess profanity—anything a person concerned with his or her future wouldn’t want a million or so people to read.Now remove almost all the adjectives and qualifiers. Your language should be vivid and open enough that the reader can fill in the blanks. For instance, passionate people exude passion; they don’t have to point out that they’re “passionate.”Good question—it made me think. Hope that helps.

It’s actually very easy to write about yourself, you just have to know who you really are. Though, if you are not sure, you’ll have to wait for a few days First of all, you should see what kind of person you are. I suggest to get a journal and write about what kind of attitude you have towards your family and friends. Write something like this: James: kind, friendly and a little bit aggressive. This will help you about your personality and feelings. Next, you should see what you like to do. For example, if you like to play soccer, you are energetic. If you like to study, you are smart. Your activities depend on your characteristic. Last but not least, ask people how they think you are. Their opinions will tell you how they think about you and you will be able to write about yourself in no time.

First: Think long and hard what you want to say about yourself in just a paragraph. Second: Write a shitty first draft of your paragraph. Third: Read your shitty first draft over three times and decide how you can improve what you have written. Fourth: Revise your paragraph accordingly. Fifth: Read your revised paragraph and think long and hard as to how you can improve what you’ve written. Keep this up until you have written the best possible paragraph you can.

response.answer_text: Change the pronoun: write about “he" instead of “I.” Changing the pronoun ranks among the most powerful tools in a writer's kit. Here, using “he" serves to objectify the subject, thereby allowing you to discuss the applicant's qualities in a more dispassionate way. (It will make you less embarassed to be writing about yourself.) If you're writing, say, a resume, don't forget to change the “he" back to “I" before handing it in! Contrariwise, if writing fiction or a blurb about yourself for publication, leave it as “he.”

Put pen to paper - fingers to keyboard or chisel and hammer to granite and write! Writing is not much different from practicing an instrument, the more you practice the better you play…and the more you write etc. Write down every thought that comes into your head - don’t discard anything - but when you’re done edit. Ferociously. Unforgivingly. Leave out opinion include only facts. Here’s a suggestion: Read Stephen King’s masterful “On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft’ and always keep a copy of Strunk & White’s ‘The Elements of Style’ on the desk - you’ll be surprised at how helpful they will be across the life of your writing career.

Take some time to meditate about the times in your life from early childhood through the teenage years, your home life, your early and present work life, your education and various relationships. What has influenced you, what has changed your thinking, how have you matured, what do you genuinely like about yourself and feel proud of? Say NOTHING negative and whatever you say, be sure it’s honest. Write down some ideas that come to you while you’re meditating, then look it all over and write your paragraph.

I would think about the experiences you have had and what makes you unique. Write down a list of your experiences and accomplishments. Next, write down unique personality traits that make you, you. From each list, choose what you think is most important and formulate a paragraph from there. If you are writing from a business/service standpoint, focus on how you can help people and make it about your audience and what you can do for them. I hope this helps.

You should know youself, this will help you to write a good paragraph about yourself. Write with heart not with brain. Write the truth not the lie. Also try to explain your modes and feeling with the help of poetry. Write your beneficial habits. Write your hobies. Write every single detail about personality. Write your likes and dislikes. Explain your ideolgy with detail. Hope it helps —

I think honesty is the key, but first you need to decide what exactly you want to relate to your intended audience. I would suggest that you try to write more about what you would like people to learn about you rather than what you think people want to hear you say. Be fearless and confident in your measure of worth, for yourself and your intended audience.

Now just know this is no master answer… I would combine a few answers if I were you, but I would personally write about a dozen paragraphs, take a night to sleep on it, then the next day when I’m uo and awake, I'd read them all and combine the best parts of each. Also write it in sections with a nice Segway between each to make it flow perfectly and ask others to read it and criticize it in a good way so you get it perfect,

first things first put yourself in a good mood weather that means smoking up baby’s leg of ganja, or going for a walk on the beach; put your self in a positive mental space; and imagine your greatest flaw being whispered in your ear and replace that with the words “actually I’m a bit of a perfectionist” now you are ready to begin, extenuate authenticity over cliches, real experience and self deprecation, over wisdom and remember the lowest common denominator. Now throw that all away and rewrite it.

I used to tell this to my Education students when they had to write a letter to the registrar of the Faculty which held equal value in the Registrar’s mind to the results of a 4 year degree: Don’t write it about yourself. Write it about others. Write it about how the people with whom you have been involved have succeeded. Nobody wants a teacher who is the light at the head of the class. Everybody wants the teacher who makes the kids in the class what it’s all about.

First, know who your audience is… write something that will grab the attention of the reader, ignite pain/pleasure, describe the situation, make a call to action (if appropriate) But a lot depends on the context in which you’re operating; what’s the purpose behind your writing; what’s the desired outcome Really context matters and you didn’t provide any

For a start, you’re writing a paragraph, not a book, so it shouldn’t be too long. I notice you’ve had some helpful advice already, so I’m not going too repeat what those good folk have already spelled out. All I would say, Chris, is that you might as well have a few goes at it and see if any particular one of them tells more than the others about the kind of person you are. That’s something that tends to get missed out very often - yet it’s one of the main things you should be trying to get across.

If I knew the answer to that, they’d be making a movie about my life! ;) Seriously, sit down with a couple of close friends and have them help you describe yourself. Write out a paragraph of what you think it ought to be, and then get their input on what it should be. Refine it until you are satisfied that it says what you want it to say and your friends feel is accurate.

You would probably need more than a paragraph to write about your self in anything but the broadest sense. If you have to then in the first sentence introduce something about yourself. Explain in two sentences then write conclusion in last sentence

response.answer_text: Think about what you like, and what you don’t like. Think about what you do every day, how you do it, why you do it, who you do it with, and write all that. Then, you can edit it if you want.

Write honestly, in third person, and use your best attributes. Such as: Chris Kasman is happily married, (single, divorced); loves to travel,(play football, drink select single malt Scotch, etc) and so on. Don't lie, build up your strengths, be positive. Good luck.

Ooooph, this depends on what it is for. You're going to want to highlight different aspects of yourself for different purposes. But, in general and when i feel the writing just needs to be honest, I defer to Langston Hughes' poem Theme for English B. Sorry it's a bit of deflection, but it fits perfectly here.
Try writing it in the third person first. That will give you 1 degree of separation.
